user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of new_connections_list_process_:
```c
static void
new_connections_list_process_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *local_head;
  struct MHD_Connection *local_tail;
  mhd_assert (daemon->have_new);
  mhd_assert (MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon));

  /* Detach DL-list of new connections from the daemon for
   * following local processing. */
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
  mhd_assert (NULL != daemon->new_connections_head);
  local_head = daemon->new_connections_head;
  local_tail = daemon->new_connections_tail;
  daemon->new_connections_head = NULL;
  daemon->new_connections_tail = NULL;
  daemon->have_new = false;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
  (void) local_head; /* Mute compiler warning */

  /* Process new connections in FIFO order. */
  do
  {
    struct MHD_Connection *c;   /**< Currently processed connection */

    c = local_tail;
    DLL_remove (local_head,
                local_tail,
                c);
    mhd_assert (daemon == c->daemon);
    if (MHD_NO == new_connection_process_ (daemon, c))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Failed to start serving new connection.\n"));
#endif
      (void) 0;
    }
  } while (NULL != local_tail);

}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Failed to start serving new connection.\n"));
explanation: I did not mark the rest of the code as suspicious because it only uses standard C constructs: function definition, pointer declarations, assignments, boolean literal assignment (false), standard control flow (do/while, if), standard (void) casts to suppress warnings, and C-style comments. No explicit compiler-extension tokens (such as GCC/Clang __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expression ({ ... }), nested functions, computed goto labels (&&label), or other compiler-specific keywords) appear directly in the shown code. The listed fragments are macro or function-like invocations whose definitions are not present in the snippet; those definitions may employ compiler-specific extensions, so they should be investigated. The remainder of the code contains no indications of language extensions that require inspection.
